oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Interview - Paul Hemphill - 2005-09-17
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Interview with author Paul Hemphill about his biography titled Lovesick Blues: The Life of Hank Williams from the Ford Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on September 17, 2005. Moderated by Jay Orr.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Paul Hemphill;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Recording begins in progress and on one channel until 01:01. / (00:00) Introduction of Paul Hemphill by Jay Orr / (03:20) Paul reads the prologue to the book / (20:19) Paul talks about his inspiration for writing the Hank book / (19:58) Oscar Davis working with Hank and story about Hank's drinking / (23:27) Confirming and dispelling stories on Hank / (26:17) Inspiration for writing the book / (28:30) Information and research used for the book and Don Helms / (33:00) Hanks relationship with Fred Rose / (38:32) Hank's relationship with his alter ego Luke the Drifter / (39:44) Talks about the song I'm So Lonesome I Could Cry / (43:14) Talks about Hank's death and the myths and circumstances surrounding it / (51:49) Question from the audience regarding Lillie Stone and the writing of the song I Saw The Light / (55:02) Hank's continuing influence on current artists and Hemphill's style in writing this book /

(57:03) Speculation on Hank's early music influences and the scene in Georgiana Alabama / (58:30) Talks about Rufus "Tee Tot" Payne / (01:01:30) Comments about attending the Grand Ole Opry and missing Hank Williams / (01:02:54) Final comments / PROGRAM END.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Hemphill, Paul, 1936-2009; Country Music Hall of Fame & Museum (Nashville, Tenn.);
